claim: If you swallow gum, nothing will happen to you.

supporting.text: Gum is indigestible and passes through the digestive system intact, so swallowing it poses no harm.

attacks.text: Gum is indigestible and passes through the digestive system intact, so swallowing it poses no harm.
Swallowing large amounts of gum can lead to intestinal blockages, especially in children.
Gum may contain artificial sweeteners or other additives that could cause digestive discomfort when swallowed.
Repeatedly swallowing gum over time could accumulate in the digestive tract, potentially causing issues.
Intestinal blockages from gum are extremely rare and usually only occur with very large quantities.
Most artificial sweeteners in gum are approved as safe for consumption in small amounts.
The human digestive system is capable of passing small amounts of gum without accumulation.
Even rare cases of blockage demonstrate that swallowing gum can potentially cause harm.
Some individuals may have sensitivities to certain additives that could cause reactions.

supporting.text: Medical studies show that small amounts of swallowed gum are excreted naturally without causing blockages.

attacks.text: Medical studies show that small amounts of swallowed gum are excreted naturally without causing blockages.
Some individuals may experience gastrointestinal discomfort or mild blockages if they swallow gum frequently or in large quantities.
Gum is indigestible and could potentially accumulate in the digestive tract over time, leading to complications.
Most people do not swallow enough gum for accumulation to become a serious issue, as occasional ingestion is harmless.
The digestive system is capable of passing small indigestible objects, including gum, without significant risk.
Even occasional ingestion can pose risks for individuals with pre-existing digestive conditions.
There are documented cases of gum contributing to blockages, particularly in children.

supporting.text: The human body cannot break down gum's synthetic components, so it is eliminated without absorption.

attacks.text: The human body cannot break down gum's synthetic components, so it is eliminated without absorption.
Swallowing large amounts of gum can lead to intestinal blockages, especially in children.
Even if not absorbed, gum can stick to the digestive tract and cause discomfort or minor issues.
Intestinal blockages from gum are extremely rare and usually occur only with excessive consumption.
The digestive system is designed to pass indigestible materials, including gum, without significant issues.
Discomfort from swallowed gum is temporary and resolves naturally as the gum passes through the system.
Medical case reports document instances where gum caused serious blockages, proving the risk is real.
Children's smaller digestive tracts make them more susceptible to blockages from even small amounts of gum.

supporting.text: Swallowing large quantities of gum repeatedly can lead to intestinal blockages, contradicting the claim.

attacks.text: Swallowing large quantities of gum repeatedly can lead to intestinal blockages, contradicting the claim.
Gum is designed to be indigestible but passes through the digestive system without causing blockages in normal quantities.
There are no documented cases of gum causing serious intestinal blockages in healthy individuals.
Even small amounts of gum can accumulate over time and contribute to blockages, especially in children.
Lack of documented cases does not prove safety; many minor blockages may go unreported.
The human digestive system can handle indigestible materials like gum without issues, as evidenced by daily consumption.
Medical literature focuses on extreme cases, suggesting routine gum swallowing is harmless for most people.

supporting.text: Children who swallow gum may experience digestive discomfort or choking hazards, disproving the claim.

attacks.text: Children who swallow gum may experience digestive discomfort or choking hazards, disproving the claim.
Gum is designed to be indigestible but passes harmlessly through the digestive system in most cases, including for children.
Choking hazards from gum are extremely rare and usually occur only if the gum is swallowed improperly or in very large quantities.
Even if gum passes through the digestive system, it can still cause blockages or discomfort in children with sensitive digestive systems.
Children are more likely to swallow gum improperly due to their smaller airways and less developed chewing habits, increasing choking risks.
Medical studies show that gum-related digestive blockages in children are statistically negligible compared to other common hazards.
Proper parental supervision and teaching children not to swallow gum can mitigate almost all choking risks.

supporting.text: Gum can stick to the esophagus or intestines in rare cases, causing medical complications.

attacks.text: Gum can stick to the esophagus or intestines in rare cases, causing medical complications.
The human digestive system is highly efficient and can pass gum without issues in the vast majority of cases.
There is no documented evidence of gum causing serious blockages in healthy individuals.
Medical complications from swallowed gum are so rare that they are statistically negligible.
Even if rare, documented cases of gum causing blockages in children and individuals with pre-existing conditions prove it is possible.
Lack of widespread documentation does not mean the risk is zero, especially for vulnerable populations.
Statistical rarity does not eliminate the need for caution, as even rare events can have severe consequences.
Cases involving children or pre-existing conditions are outliers and not representative of the general population.
Focusing on extreme edge cases exaggerates the perceived risk for the average person.
